class.name: BulletCurvesData2D
class.brief_description: Holds data for controlling bullet movement and rotation using curves in 2D. Can override [BulletSpeedData2D] and [BulletRotationData2D].

members.member: The speed at which the bullet rotates to face the adjusted direction defined by the X and Y direction curves.

The curve used to control the movement speed of the bullet over time. The X-axis represents the normalized time (0 start of life to 1 end of life) of the bullet's lifetime, while the Y-axis represents the speed value at that particular time.
Note that you can set [member movement_use_unit_curve] to false to have absolute values for the time.

Whether to use a unit curve for the movement speed curve. If [code]true[/code], the X-axis of the curve is normalized (0 start of life to 1 end of life) based on the bullet's lifetime. If [code]false[/code], the X-axis represents absolute time values (at exactly X lifetime have THIS Y SPEED value).
Whether the bullet should rotate to face the adjusted direction defined by the X and Y direction curves.

The curve used to control the rotation speed of the bullet over time. The X-axis represents the normalized time (0 start of life to 1 end of life) of the bullet's lifetime, while the Y-axis represents the rotation speed value at that particular time.
Note that you can set [member rotation_use_unit_curve] to false to have absolute values for the time.

Whether to use a unit curve for the rotation speed curve. If [code]true[/code], the X-axis of the curve is normalized (0 start of life to 1 end of life) based on the bullet's lifetime. If [code]false[/code], the X-axis represents absolute time values (at exactly X lifetime have THIS Y ROTATION SPEED value).

The curve used to control the bullet's direction adjustment along the X-axis over time. The X-axis represents the normalized time (0 start of life to 1 end of life) of the bullet's lifetime, while the Y-axis represents the direction adjustment value at that particular time.
Note that you can set [member x_direction_use_unit_curve] to false to have absolute values for the time.
Whether the X direction curve should be applied additively to the bullet's current direction or override it entirely.
A multiplier for the X direction curve's output value, allowing you to scale the effect of the curve on the bullet's direction.

Whether to use a unit curve for the X direction curve. If [code]true[/code], the X-axis of the curve is normalized (0 start of life to 1 end of life) based on the bullet's lifetime. If [code]false[/code], the X-axis represents absolute time values (at exactly X lifetime have THIS Y DIRECTION value).

The curve used to control the bullet's direction adjustment along the Y-axis over time. The X-axis represents the normalized time (0 start of life to 1 end of life) of the bullet's lifetime, while the Y-axis represents the direction adjustment value at that particular time.
Note that you can set [member y_direction_use_unit_curve] to false to have absolute values for the time.
Whether the Y direction curve should be applied additively to the bullet's current direction or override it entirely.
A multiplier for the Y direction curve's output value, allowing you to scale the effect of the curve on the bullet's direction.

Whether to use a unit curve for the Y direction curve. If [code]true[/code], the X-axis of the curve is normalized (0 start of life to 1 end of life) based on the bullet's lifetime. If [code]false[/code], the X-axis represents absolute time values (at exactly X lifetime have THIS Y DIRECTION value).
